Debug: raw langdetect output: [('ko', 0.9999995211930662)]
...
Detected languages: [('ko', 0.9999995211930662)]

The code ko is the ISO 639-1 language code for Korean. üá∞üá∑

So langdetect is saying:

  • It thinks the text is Korean (ko)
  • With probability ‚âà 0.9999995 (essentially 100%)

That explains the error: your validator expected "zh-tw" (Traditional Chinese), but the detector decided the input looks like Korean instead.

üëâ Quick mapping reminder from langdetect / ISO 639-1:

  • zh ‚Üí Chinese (unspecified)
  • zh-cn ‚Üí Simplified Chinese (China)
  • zh-tw (or hant in your mapping) ‚Üí Traditional Chinese (Taiwan)
  • ja ‚Üí Japanese
  • ko ‚Üí Korean
  • ne ‚Üí Nepali
  • hi ‚Üí Hindi

Do you want me to suggest how you could harden your validator so it doesn‚Äôt fail when langdetect misclassifies (e.g. allowing a fallback if the target script characters are clearly Chinese but the code comes out as ko)?
